subject: Data
title: The Confidence Interval: How Sure Is Sure?
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on The Confidence Interval: How Sure Is Sure?.

hook.text: A headline says 'the average American eats 23 pounds of pizza per year.' How much can you trust that number?

buildup.text: Confidence intervals give a range â€” 'we're 95% confident the true value is between 21 and 25 pounds.'

discovery.text: Jerzy Neyman formalized confidence intervals in 1937, giving statistics a built-in uncertainty measure.

twist.text: Most people misinterpret them. A 95% CI doesn't mean there's a 95% chance the truth is inside.

climax.text: Confidence intervals remind us that every measurement has uncertainty â€” and that's okay.

punchline.text: Honest data always admits what it doesn't know.

quiz.question: Who formalized the concept of confidence intervals?
